Text:
Either

    Text = Text.decode('utf-8')
or

    Text = Text.encode('iso-8859-2').decode('utf-8')

Should do what you want, but might not. Fiddle around with the `error` keyword argument if you keep getting errors.

http://docs.python.org/release/2.5/lib/string-methods.html

Either

    Text = Text.decode('utf-8')
or

    Text = Text.encode('iso-8859-2').decode('utf-8')

Should do what you want, but might not. Fiddle around with the `error` keyword argument if you keep getting errors.

http://docs.python.org/release/2.5/lib/string-methods.html

If I have things switched around like Tim says, then it'd be

    Text = Text.encode('utf-8')
or

    Text = Text.decode('iso-8859-2').encode('utf-8')

...Or if I'm really confused, then it might be

    Text = Text.decode('iso-8859-2')

or something like that.

Text:
Text = Text.decode('iso-8859-2')

might be all you need, if Text starts out as an 8-bit string that was encoded with iso-8859-2.

If not, then just play around with the `encode()` and `decode()` methods and the error handling methods used with them: http://docs.python.org/release/2.5/lib/string-methods.html

(Took out most of the stuff in my answer that wasn't really necessary, considering what the question states.)

Text = Text.decode('iso-8859-2')

might be all you need, if Text starts out as an 8-bit string that was encoded with iso-8859-2. If it needs to be sent as a UTF-8 string or something, however, then you'd probably want to use

    Text = Text.decode('utf-8')

If neither of those, then just play around with the `decode()` and `encode()` methods and the error handling methods used with them: http://docs.python.org/release/2.5/lib/string-methods.html

(Took out most of the stuff in my answer that wasn't really necessary, considering what the question states.)
